DataElement.preferredDefinition: Cyclic Redundancy Code (CRC) CHECKSUM for the NAACCR record in which it resides.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Cyclic Redundancy Code (CRC) CHECKSUM for the NAACCR record in which it resides.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The type of change made to an element.:To take precedence over and countermand, thereby allowing an activity to continue despite a warning or error.

Concepts.definition: The type of change made to an element.
To take precedence over and countermand, thereby allowing an activity to continue despite a warning or error.

Property.preferredDefinition: A computed value which depends on the contents of a block of data and which is transmitted or stored along with the data in order to detect corruption of the data. The receiving system recomputes the checksum based upon the received data and compares this value with the one sent with the data. If the two values are the same, the receiver has some confidence that the data was received correctly. (http://foldoc.doc.ic.ac.uk/foldoc/foldoc.cgi?checksum)

Concepts.definition: A computed value which depends on the contents of a block of data and which is transmitted or stored along with the data in order to detect corruption of the data. (http://foldoc.doc.ic.ac.uk/foldoc/foldoc.cgi?checksum)_A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed. [Explanatory Comment: See NAACRR Data Dictionary, Eleventh Edition, for directions for calculation of a checksum value.]

ReferenceDocuments.description: For additional details see NAACCR, Standards for Cancer Registries Volume II, Version 11.1 Data Standards and Data Dictionary (5/4/06)

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRC Checksum Description
ReferenceDocuments.description: A unique value is calculated for each unique record in a NAACCR file. The value is calculated by applying a CRC algorithm to all data fields of the NAACCR record (excluding the CRC CHECKSUM field). Following a transmission, the CRC CHECKSUM can be recalculated and compared with the transmitted CHECKSUM. Identical values indicate an error-free transmission; differing values indicate an error in transmission. The algorithm recommended by NAACCR is on the NAACCR website at: http://www.naaccr.org. Users must provide recipients of the data with the algorithm used to create the data transmission file. Otherwise, the item should be left blank.
